The SBA would need to update regulations in 13 C.F.R. Parts 120-121 to implement these new restrictions on eligibility for SBA assistance.

Immigration & Citizenship - Legal Perman.justification: The bill prohibits small business concerns from having more than 25% ownership by citizens of China. This could substantially limit the ability of many legal permanent residents originally from China to access SBA programs and assistance.
Immigration & Citizenship - Legal Perman.estimated_monetary_impact: $5,000-$10,000/year in lost access to loans, grants, and resources

Race - Asian.justification: The 25% ownership restriction on citizens of China is likely to disproportionately impact Asian Americans, especially those with ties to China, in accessing SBA programs as small business owners. This reduces their access to valuable business assistance.
Race - Asian.estimated_monetary_impact: $1,000-$5,000/year in lost access to loans and resources

Immigration & Citizenship - Temporary Vi.justification: Temporary visa holders from China would be barred from owning more than 25% of a small business concern in the U.S., limiting their opportunities. However, the impact is less severe than for permanent residents.
Immigration & Citizenship - Temporary Vi.estimated_monetary_impact: $500-$2,000/year in lost access to loans and resources

Race - White.justification: The bill does not have any specific impact, positive or negative, on white Americans as a racial group. The China-related ownership restrictions are based on citizenship, not race.

Employment - Private Sector.justification: While the bill restricts some small business ownership, the impact on private sector workers overall is minimal. It does not substantially affect employment opportunities or benefits for the broader private workforce.

118_hr_9890.title: Reporting Medical Debt Payments as Positive Consumer Credit Information Act of 2024

summary_of_changes: Allows furnishers of medical debt information to report paid or settled medical debt to consumer reporting agencies for up to one year
Allows furnishers to report satisfactory performance of consumers meeting obligations of a medical debt payment plan
Requires consumer reporting agencies and credit score providers to adopt reasonable procedures to include this positive medical debt information in consumer reports and credit scores
modification_summary.legal_impact: The changes would allow certain positive medical debt payment information to be included in consumer credit reports and scores, potentially benefiting consumers who responsibly pay off or manage their medical debt. It places new requirements on credit reporting agencies and score providers to incorporate this information.
modification_summary.relevance_explanation: The changes moderately impact how medical debt is reported and factored into credit reports and scores, which could have some benefits for certain consumers. However, medical debt reporting is a relatively narrow aspect of the broader credit reporting system.

before_and_after.before: The existing Fair Credit Reporting Act text does not specifically address the reporting of positive medical debt payment information.
before_and_after.after: If passed, the FCRA would be amended to add a new subsection 623(f) titled 'Positive Credit Reporting of Medical Debt Payments'. This subsection would allow furnishers to report paid, settled or satisfactory payment plan performance on medical debt to CRAs for inclusion in reports and scores, and would require CRAs and score providers to reasonably incorporate this positive information.

Health - Uninsured.justification: By allowing positive credit reporting for medical debt payments, this bill expands access to credit and financial services for uninsured individuals who may have struggled with medical bills in the past. It removes a barrier that previously excluded this group.
Health - Uninsured.estimated_monetary_impact: $500-$2,000/year in improved credit access and lower borrowing costs

Income - Low-Income.justification: Lower-income individuals are more likely to have medical debt and difficulty paying. Allowing positive credit reporting for medical payments could meaningfully boost credit scores and expand access to affordable credit for this group, providing a noticeable financial benefit.
Income - Low-Income.estimated_monetary_impact: $300-$1,000/year in reduced interest rates and fees from improved credit

Race - Black or African American.justification: Black Americans face higher rates of medical debt and uninsurance. The bill signals improved inclusion in credit reporting for medical payments, with a moderate economic effect by simplifying credit building for affected individuals in this group.

Age - 25-34 years old.justification: Younger adults often have less insurance coverage and more volatile finances. Recognizing timely medical debt payments could help build their credit faster, signaling improved inclusion with a moderate economic impact for those affected.

Education - Student Loan Borrowers.justification: Student loan borrowers may benefit from improved credit reporting for medical debt, but the tangible impact is likely minimal, as medical and student debts are separate. At most a symbolic gain for this group.

summary_of_changes: Establishes American Dream Accounts for every child born in the U.S., initially seeded with $5,000 by the government
Provides an additional $10,000 to Accounts of individuals who serve at least 12 months in the Peace Corps or AmeriCorps before age 26
Allows Account holders to request disbursement between ages 18-26 if they earn a high school diploma or equivalent
Establishes an Office of the American Dream to manage the Accounts
Makes contributions and distributions tax-exempt
Requires developing a website and mobile app for Account holders to access information
Promotes financial literacy education in schools
modification_summary.legal_impact: This bill would establish a major new government program to provide every child born in the U.S. with a $5,000 investment account. It aims to promote wealth-building and financial education, especially for low-income families. However, it would be very costly and significantly expand the scope of the Social Security Administration.
modification_summary.relevance_explanation: The bill proposes a major new government program that would impact every child born in the United States. While tangentially related to the Peace Corps, the primary focus is on establishing universal investment accounts for children.

before_and_after.before: The Congress of the United States declares that it is the policy of the United States and the purpose of this chapter to promote world peace and friendship through a Peace Corps, which shall make available to interested countries and areas men and women of the United States qualified for service abroad and willing to serve, under conditions of hardship if necessary, to help the peoples of such countries and areas in meeting their needs for trained manpower, particularly in meeting the basic needs of those living in the poorest areas of such countries, and to help promote a better understanding of the American people on the part of the peoples served and a better understanding of other peoples on the part of the American people. The Congress declares that it is the policy of the United States and a purpose of the Peace Corps to maintain, to the maximum extent appropriate and consistent with programmatic and fiscal considerations, a volunteer corps of at least 10,000 individuals.
before_and_after.after: The proposed bill does not directly amend 22 U.S.C. 2501. However, it references the Peace Corps Act, stating that individuals who serve at least 12 months in the Peace Corps before age 26 would receive an additional $10,000 in their American Dream Account established under the bill. This provides an incentive for Peace Corps service but does not fundamentally change the mission or policies stated in 22 U.S.C. 2501.

summary_of_changes: Directs the Social Security Commissioner to establish an American Dream Account for each child born or naturalized in the U.S., with an initial $5,000 contribution
Provides an additional $10,000 contribution if the individual serves in the Peace Corps or AmeriCorps for 12+ months before age 26
Allows the individual to request disbursement of the funds between ages 18-25 if they earn a high school diploma, equivalent, or disability waiver
Creates an Office of the American Dream to oversee the accounts and investments
Makes the accounts and disbursements tax-exempt
Establishes grants for financial literacy education in schools
modification_summary.legal_impact: This bill would create a major new entitlement program providing investment accounts to all children born or naturalized in the U.S. It expands the responsibilities of the Social Security Administration. The accounts would be exempt from taxation and benefit eligibility determinations.
modification_summary.relevance_explanation: If passed, this bill would establish a significant new program impacting all children in the U.S. and involving major government appropriations. However, the section of U.S. Code it directly amends is relatively narrow in scope.

before_and_after.before: The term "approved national service position" means a national service position for which the Corporation has approved the provision of a national service educational award described in section 12603 of this title as one of the benefits to be provided for successful service in the position.
before_and_after.after: The term "approved national service position" means a national service position for which the Corporation has approved the provision of a national service educational award described in section 12603 of this title as one of the benefits to be provided for successful service in the position. An individual serving in an approved national service position for 12 months prior to age 26 shall be eligible for a $10,000 contribution to their American Dream Account established under the American Dream Accounts Act of 2024.

Age - 0-12 years old.justification: Every child born in the U.S. after the bill's enactment will receive a $5,000 contribution to an American Dream Account, providing a substantial financial benefit from birth.

Age - 18-24 years old.justification: Young adults in this age range will be eligible to withdraw funds from their American Dream Accounts for approved purposes like education or starting a business, providing access to valuable seed capital. Those who perform national service can also receive an additional $10,000 bonus contribution.

Education - K-12 Students.justification: The bill directs the Secretary of Education to disseminate best practices for teaching financial literacy to K-12 schools and establishes grants for professional development for teachers in personal finance education. This will expand access to financial education for many students.

Income - Low-Income.justification: Low-income individuals stand to benefit the most from the seed funding provided by American Dream Accounts, which can provide a foundation for upward mobility. The accounts are also exempt from means testing for benefits eligibility.
Income - Low-Income.estimated_monetary_impact: $5,000 in starting wealth that grows over time

Race - Black or African American.justification: Given continuing racial wealth gaps, universal seed funding for all children will disproportionately benefit Black Americans in expanding access to education, entrepreneurship and more stable financial footing from a young age.
